questions.text: Nitrogenous waste is excreted from the body in the form of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Urea

Explanation:

  • Ammonia is produced during the breakdown of amino acids and by gut bacteria in humans.
  • However, ammonia is highly toxic, especially to the brain, if its levels in the blood rise too high.
  • To prevent this toxicity, the body converts ammonia into urea through the urea cycle.
  • This process occurs in the liver, where ammonia is safely transformed into urea, a less toxic substance.
  • Urea is then excreted from the body through the urine, effectively removing excess nitrogenous waste from the body.

Incorrect Options:

Nitric oxide (Option B): A signaling molecule involved in vasodilation and other processes, not nitrogenous waste excretion.

Ammonia (Option C): While ammonia is produced during amino acid breakdown, it is toxic at high levels and is converted into urea for excretion.

Glutamine (Option D): An amino acid involved in nitrogen transport but not directly excreted as a nitrogenous waste product.

questions.text: If you need to diagnose a syndromic illness such as meningitis, which of the following diagnostic techniques is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Multiplex PCR

Explanation:

When diagnosing a syndromic illness such as meningitis, which may be caused by various pathogens including bacteria, viruses, and fungi, Multiplex PCR is used because it can simultaneously detect multiple causative agents.

  • Amplifies multiple DNA targets in one reaction using several primer sets.
  • Saves time and reduces costs by testing multiple pathogens simultaneously.
  • Commonly used in clinical diagnostics and genetic testing.
  • Requires careful primer design to avoid interference.
  • Offers high sensitivity and specificity when well optimized.
  • Ideal for syndromic testing where multiple pathogens may be involved.

Incorrect Options:

Uniplex PCR (Option B) detects only one target per reaction, making it less efficient for syndromic testing.

Attributed PCR (Option C) is not a commonly used term in molecular diagnostics.

Nested PCR (Option D) is a two-step PCR designed to increase sensitivity and specificity but usually targets a single pathogen per test.

questions.text: Which of the following substances, at the given concentration, makes water unsuitable for human consumption according to safety standards?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cadmium - 0.3 mg/L

Explanation:

The unsafe substance here is cadmium at 0.3 mg/L, because it exceeds permissible limits for drinking water.

  • WHO & BIS (Bureau of Indian Standards) limits:
    • Fluoride: desirable ~1.0 mg/L (max 1.5 mg/L) → 0.8 mg/L is safe.
    • Cadmium: safe limit is 0.003 mg/L (3 µg/L) → 0.3 mg/L is 100× higher, toxic.
    • Chloride: permissible up to 250 mg/L → 200 mg/L is safe.
    • Calcium: desirable up to 75 mg/L (max 200 mg/L) → 7 mg/L is safe.

Toxicity of cadmium in water:

  • Chronic exposure → kidney damage (proximal tubular dysfunction), bone demineralisation (Itai-Itai disease in Japan), carcinogenic effects.
  • Often from industrial waste, batteries, and electroplating runoff.

questions.text: In a village of Assam, a man is observed walking with the help of a stick and has genu valgum. Many people in the same village present with similar symptoms. What is the most probable cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Skeletal fluorosis

Explanation:

The presence of genu valgum and multiple affected individuals in an Assam village suggests Skeletal Fluorosis, a condition common in areas with high fluoride levels in drinking water, leading to bone pain, stiffness, joint deformities, and walking difficulty.

  • Cause: Chronic ingestion of high levels of fluoride, usually through drinking water.
  • Endemic Areas: Common in parts of India, especially Assam, Andhra Pradesh, and Rajasthan.
  • Symptoms:
    • Bone pain and joint stiffness
    • Genu valgum (knock knees), difficulty walking
    • May progress to crippling deformities
  • X-ray findings: Increased bone density (osteosclerosis)
  • Prevention: Use of fluoride-free water, defluoridation techniques
  • Treatment: Primarily supportive; address deformities and improve nutrition.

Fluorine content in water

Related symptoms

<0.5mg/L

Dental caries

>1.5mg/L

Dental fluorosis

3-6mg/L

Skeletal fluorosis

>10mg/L

Crippling fluorosis

Incorrect Options:

  • Calcium deficiency (Option A) and Vitamin D deficiency (Osteomalacia) (Option D) cause bone pain and weakness, but are less likely to occur in clusters.
  • Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) (Option B) affects collagen synthesis and presents with bleeding gums, petechiae, not typically genu valgum.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic with abdominal pain, irritability, and developmental delay. On examination, the child has pallor and a bluish line on the gums. Laboratory tests reveal microcytic anemia, and a peripheral blood smear shows red blood cells with basophilic stippling. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lead poisoning

Explanation:

  • Classic signs of Lead Poisoning include abdominal pain, irritability, developmental delay, pallor, and a bluish line on the gums ( Burtonian’s or Burton’s line), along with laboratory findings of microcytic anemia and basophilic stippling on the peripheral smear.

Source

Exposure to lead from paint, contaminated soil, or old pipes.

Enzymes inhibited
  • Ferrochelatase
  • ALA-dehydratase
  • Coproporphyrinogen oxidase).

Clinical features
  • Facial pallor: Circumoral (vasospasm) → Earliest and most specific feature
  • Lead line or Burtonian lines: Stippled blue line observed on the gums, resulting from a subepithelial deposit of granules.

 

 

  • Lead osteopathy/Lead line (Bone-line): Calcium deposition occurs at the growth plates of bones (specifically the lower end of the femur and the upper end of the tibia).
  • Lead palsy: Predominantly motor features → (dry belly ache, wrist drop - radial nerve), foot drop - common peroneal nerve).
  • Blood picture: Microcytic-hypochromic anemia, Cabot rings in RBCs, Sideroblasts (nucleated red cells), Anisocytosis, Poikilocytosis, Polycythemia
  • Basophilic stippling or Punctate basophilia

 ​​​​​​​

  • Colic and constipation (Painter's Colic or Devonshire colic) → Spasmodic pain relieved by pressure (at night).
  • Saturnine gout (due to decreased excretion of uric acid)
  • Encephalopathy
  • Reproductive system (amenorrhea, dysmenorrhea, abortion, sterility derangments)
  • CVS and Kidney (Hypertension, arteriolar degeneration, nephritis).

Treatment

Remove lead exposure and chelation therapy (e.g., EDTA, dimercaprol).

Incorrect Options:

  • Iron deficiency anemia (Option A) does not present with basophilic stippling or Burton’s line.
  • Sideroblastic anemia (Option B) shows ring sideroblasts in bone marrow but not Burton’s line or neurological symptoms.
  • Thalassemia minor (Option D) has microcytic anemia but lacks lead poisoning features.

questions.text: Cyanide and carbon monoxide act on which of the heme proteins:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cytochrome c oxidase

Explanation:

  • Cyanide (CN⁻) and carbon monoxide (CO) are potent inhibitors of cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV of the mitochondrial electron transport chain).
    • Cyanide: Binds irreversibly to the heme iron (Fe³⁺) in cytochrome c oxidase, blocking electron transfer to oxygen.
    • Carbon monoxide: Binds competitively to the heme iron (Fe²⁺) in cytochrome c oxidase, displacing oxygen (O₂).

 

 

Myoglobin (Option B) CO binds to myoglobin (causing cherry-red tissues), but this is not the primary lethal mechanism.

 

Catalase (Option C) Not a target of cyanide/CO toxicity (catalase breaks down H₂O₂, not involved in O₂ utilization).

 

NADH dehydrogenase (Complex I) (Option D) Inhibited by rotenone, not cyanide/CO.

Correct Answer: D) Respiratory alkalosis

Explanation:

At high altitudes, hypoxia triggers hyperventilation, leading to enhanced CO₂ removal and results in respiratory alkalosis.

Changes during Acclimatization

Respiratory
  • At high altitudes, lower oxygen levels stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors, increasing pulmonary ventilation.
  • This leads to enhanced CO2 removal, causing respiratory alkalosis.
  • Kidneys respond by excreting more bicarbonate to stabilize blood pH, causing a sustained increase in ventilation and supporting prolonged acclimatization.

Haematological
  • At high altitudes, lower PO2 boosts erythropoietin production, increasing red blood cell count.
  • This also raises 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) levels in red blood cells.
  • Initially, alkalosis shifts the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve to the left but increased 2,3-DPG shifts it to the right, improving oxygen release to tissues.

Cardiovascular

  • Hypoxia activates the sympathoadrenal axis, increasing heart rate, cardiac output, and blood pressure.
  • Increased cardiac output leads to an increase in blood flow, and hypoxia causes vasodilation in the systemic circulation, further contributing to increased blood flow and oxygen supply to the tissues.

Tissue
  • In acclimatization, skeletal muscles undergo several changes, including an increase in the number of capillaries and mitochondria and an increase in myoglobin content.
  • Further, chemicals released from the hypoxic tissues stimulate angiogenesis.

 

Metabolic acidosis (Option A) involves decreased bicarbonate levels due to conditions like diarrhea or renal failure, not high altitude.

 

Metabolic alkalosis (Option B) can occur later as a compensatory renal response to respiratory alkalosis but is not the initial effect.

 

Respiratory acidosis (Option C) results from hypoventilation and CO₂ retention.

questions.text:
A child presents with hepatomegaly and a cherry-red spot on the macula. Neurological regression is also noted. These findings are suggestive of a lysosomal storage disorder.

Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sphingomyelinase

Explanation:

A child presenting with hepatomegaly, a cherry-red spot on the macula, and neurological regression is indicative of sphingomyelinase deficiency, the enzyme deficiency responsible for Niemann-Pick Disease.

 

Disease

Enzyme Deficiency

Lipid Accumulating

Clinical Symptoms

Tay-Sachs disease (Option B ruled out)

Hexosaminidase A, S

 

Cer—Glc—Gal(NeuAc) GalNAc GM2 Ganglioside

Mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness

Fabry disease

α-Galactosidase

Cer—Glc—Gal—Gal Globotriaosylceramide

Skin rash, kidney failure (symptoms manifest fully only in males; X-linked recessive)

Metachromatic leukodystrophy (Option A ruled out)

Arylsulfatase A

 

Cer—Gal—OSO3 3-Sulfogalactosylceramide

Mental retardation and psychological disturbances in adults; demyelination

Krabbe disease (Option D ruled out)

Galactocerebrosidase

Cer—Gal Galactosylceramide

Mental retardation; myelin almost absent

Gaucher disease

β-Glucosidase

 

 

Cer—Glc Glucosylceramide

Enlarged liver and spleen, erosion of long bones, mental retardation in infants

Niemann-Pick disease types A, B

(Option C)

Sphingomyelinase

Cer—P—choline Sphingomyelin

Enlarged liver and spleen, mental retardation; fatal in early life

Farber disease

Ceramidase

Acyl—Sphingosine Ceramide

Hoarseness, dermatitis, skeletal deformation, mental retardation; fatal in early life

 

Abbreviations: Cer, ceramide; Gal, galactose; Glc, glucose; NeuAc, N-acetylne

questions.text: Name the graph and mention its application.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Plasma resonance, Ab affinity

Explanation:

The given graph is Plasma resonance or Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR), which is used to determine the determine the strength (affinity) and speed (kinetics) of antibody-antigen interactions.

 

ELISA (Option A, B) for antibody concentration typically produces a standard curve with a sigmoidal shape, plotting absorbance against antibody concentration. This method uses colorimetric detection to quantify the amount of antibody or antigen present in a sample, making it a reliable and widely used tool in diagnostics and research

questions.text:
A patient presents with a history of vomiting. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following:


	pH: 7.5
	pCO₂: 48 mm Hg
	HCO₃⁻: 30 mm Hg


 

What is the most likely acid-base abnormality?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Metabolic alkalosis

 

Explanation:

The arterial blood gas (ABG) values indicate:

  • pH: 7.5 (Alkalosis)
  • pCO₂: 48 mmHg (Elevated)
  • HCO₃⁻: 30 mEq/L (Elevated)

These findings suggest a primary metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation.

  • Primary Mechanism: Vomiting leads to loss of gastric HCl, causing an increase in bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) and resulting in metabolic alkalosis.
  • Compensatory Mechanism: The body attempts to retain CO₂ via hypoventilation (elevated pCO₂) to counteract the alkalosis.

 

  • Metabolic Acidosis (Option B) is incorrect because metabolic acidosis would present with a low pH (<7.35) and a low HCO₃⁻, which is not the case here.

 

  • Respiratory Acidosis (Option C) is incorrect because respiratory acidosis is characterized by low pH and high pCO₂, but in this case, the pH is elevated.

 

  • Respiratory Alkalosis (Option D) is incorrect because respiratory alkalosis involves low pCO₂ due to hyperventilation, whereas this patient has elevated pCO₂ as a compensatory response.

questions.text: In a 14-year-old male, a medical condition has been identified as a result of a defect in a gene responsible for DNA repair. The individual is experiencing increased pigmentation on the skin and is at a heightened risk of developing skin cancers, according to the physician. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely to be impaired in this particular condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nucleotide excision repair defect

Explanation:

In this 14-year-old male, the condition described involves increased pigmentation on the skin and a heightened risk of skin cancers. These symptoms are consistent with Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP), a disorder caused by an inability to repair UV-induced DNA damage. UV radiation can cause the formation of pyrimidine dimers (thymine dimers) in the skin cells, which, if not repaired, lead to mutations and an increased risk of cancer. The key defective mechanism in XP is Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER).

Nucleotide excision repair: Nucleotide excision repair is required when chemical damage to a segment occurs. UV mediated Pyr Pyr dimerization is observed in a segment. 30 bases are removed and then the correct bases are added

Recognition and Excision:

  • In bacteria, UvrABC proteins (uvrABC excinuclease) recognize these dimers and cleave the damaged strand on both the 5′ and 3′ sides of the lesion.
  • A short oligonucleotide containing the dimer is excised, leaving a gap in the DNA strand.
  • The gap is subsequently filled in by DNA polymerase I and sealed by DNA ligase.

Nucleotide Excision Repair in Humans:

  • A related nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway exists in humans, addressing UV-induced damage encountered during DNA synthesis.
  • Transcription-coupled repair, a type of NER, specifically targets lesions that obstruct RNA synthesis.

Clinical application:

  • Pyrimidine dimers can form in human skin cells exposed to unfiltered sunlight.
  • In xeroderma pigmentosum (XP), a genetic disorder, the inability to repair UV-induced DNA damage leads to the accumulation of mutations and a heightened risk of developing early and multiple skin cancers.
  • XP results from defects in genes coding for proteins necessary for NER of UV damage

questions.text: A child with mental retardation, blindness, and muscle weakness was investigated and was found to be deficient for Hexosaminidase-A enzyme. She is most likely suffering from ..
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tay-sachs disease

Explanation:

The child in the clinical scenario is showing signs of mental retardation, blindness, and muscle weakness, which strongly suggest a lysosomal storage disorder. Upon investigation, the child was found to be deficient in hexosaminidase A enzyme. The disease most likely causing these symptoms is Tay-Sachs disease.It is an inborn error of metabolism due to the failure of degradation of gangliosides, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A.

Lipid Storage Diseases (Sphingolipidoses):

  • They are a group of lysosomal storage diseases.

Disease

Enzyme deficiency

Features

Tay-Sachs disease

(Option C)

Hexosaminidase A
  • Mental retardation
  • Blindness
  • Muscular weakness
  • Cherry red spots in the macula

Fabry disease

(Option B ruled out)

α-Galactosidase
  • Skin rash
  • Kidney failure (full symptoms only in males
  • X-linked recessive)

Krabbe disease

(Option A ruled out)

β-Galactosidase
  • Mental retardation
  • Near absence of myelin
  • Predominant neurological manifestation and cranial nerves causing deafness and blindness.

Gaucher disease

(Option D ruled out)

β-Glucosidase
  • Enlarged liver and spleen
  • Erosion of long bones
  • Mental retardation in infants
  • Anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia

Niemann-Pick disease

Sphingomyelinase
  • Enlarged liver and spleen
  • Mental retardation
  • Fatal in early life
  • Cherry red spot in macula

Farber disease

Ceramidase
  • Hoarseness
  • Dermatitis
  • Skeletal deformation
  • Mental retardation
  • Fatal in early life

Correct Answer: A) L-arginine

Explanation:

  • Nitric oxide (NO˙) is a highly reactive free radical with an unpaired electron, making it highly reactive.
  • It is uncharged and has a short half-life (approximately 0.1 second).
  • Synthesis of Nitric Oxide:
    • NO˙ is synthesized from arginine by the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS).
    • NOS contains heme, FAD, FMN, and tetrahydrobiopterine.
    • The process utilizes NADPH and molecular oxygen.
    • Calmodulin is required to modulate NOS activity.
    • The guanidino nitrogen of arginine is incorporated into NO˙, while one oxygen atom from molecular oxygen is incorporated into NO˙ and the other into citrulline. This makes NOS a di-oxygenase enzyme.
  • Isoenzymes of NOS:
  • Mechanism of Action of Nitric Oxide:
    • NO˙ diffuses to adjacent smooth muscle cells and activates guanylate cyclase.
    • This leads to an increase in cyclic GMP levels, which activates protein kinase in smooth muscle.
    • This causes the dephosphorylation of myosin light chains, resulting in relaxation of smooth muscle (vasodilation) in blood vessels, leading to lower blood pressure.

 

L-citrulline (Option B): L-citrulline is a byproduct of nitric oxide synthesis, as it is produced from L-arginine during the enzymatic conversion to NO˙. It is not the direct precursor for nitric oxide.

Glycine (Option C): Glycine is an amino acid, but it is not involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide. It serves other functions in the body, such as being a neurotransmitter.

Lysine (Option D): L-lysine is another amino acid, but it does not play a direct role in the synthesis of nitric oxide.

questions.text: What is the order of the band in the sarcomere?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Z-I-A-H-M

Explanation:

 

 

Sarcomere

The functional unit of a myofibril, composed of alternating dark A bands and light I bands.

Z Line

A dense, narrow line that bisects the I band; contains 2 actin molecules.

I Band

The light band alternating with the dark A band; bisected by the Z line.

A Band

The dark band in the sarcomere; includes the central H zone and is composed of thick filaments.

H Zone

The lighter region in the center of the A band.

M Line

The dark line in the middle of the H zone; contains M protein.

questions.text: Which test should be done for detecting metabolite levels in inborn errors of metabolism in neonates?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tandem mass spectroscopy:

  • Tandem mass spectroscopy (MS/MS) is widely used for newborn screening for metabolic disorders.
  • It allows for the detection of multiple metabolic diseases from a single blood sample.
  • It is highly sensitive and can identify various metabolic abnormalities by analyzing specific metabolites and their precursors.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Complete blood count (CBC):

  • CBC is a common blood test used to evaluate overall health and detect a wide range of disorders, including anemia, infection, and many other diseases. However, it is not specifically designed for metabolic disease screening.

Option C - Urinalysis:

  • Useful for evaluating kidney function and urinary tract issues but not comprehensive enough for metabolic disease screening

Option D - Genetic testing:

  • Identifies specific genetic mutations, often used when there is a high suspicion of a particular disorder, but not a first-line screening tool due to cost and specificity.

questions.text: The development of cataracts in patients with Diabetes Mellitus is primarily due to the accumulation of which of the following substances in the lens?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Sorbitol

 

Explanation:

Sorbitol accumulation in the lens is the primary cause of diabetic cataracts. In diabetes mellitus, chronic hyperglycaemia leads to the activation of the polyol pathway, where:

  1. Glucose is converted to sorbitol by aldose reductase.
  2. Sorbitol is slowly metabolised to fructose by sorbitol dehydrogenase.
  3. In the lens, sorbitol accumulates, causing:
    • Osmotic stress → water influx → lens swelling
    • Oxidative stress → protein damage → cataract formation

Diabetic cataracts typically present as snowflake cataracts in younger individuals or as accelerated senile cataracts.

 

  • Dulcitol (Option B) is incorrect because dulcitol (galactitol) accumulates in galactosemia, not diabetes. It causes galactose-induced cataracts due to galactokinase or GALT deficiency.

 

  • Mannitol (Option C) is incorrect because mannitol is an exogenous osmotic diuretic and does not accumulate in the lens.

 

  • Galactitol (Option D) is incorrect because it is another name for dulcitol, and its accumulation is linked to galactosemia, not diabetes.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is typically elevated in prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Acid phosphatase

 

Explanation:

Acid phosphatase, specifically prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP), is an enzyme that is elevated in prostate cancer, particularly in advanced or metastatic cases. PAP was historically used as a tumour marker for prostate cancer, though prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is now the preferred marker.

  • Significance:
    • Elevated in prostate cancer with bone metastases
    • Can be used to monitor disease progression
    • Less commonly used now due to the superior sensitivity of PSA

 

  • Alkaline Phosphatase (Option B) is incorrect because while alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is elevated in bone metastases, it is not specific for prostate cancer and can also be seen in liver disease and bone disorders.

 

  • Lactate Dehydrogenase (Option C) is incorrect because LDH is a non-specific marker of cell turnover and is elevated in various malignancies, not just prostate cancer.

 

  • Alpha-Fetoprotein (Option D) is incorrect because AFP is primarily a marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and germ cell tumours, not prostate cancer.
